attributes.title: Binding and Contingency Learning
attributes.description: Exploration of the relationship between contingency learning and binding

summary.value: This project contains all the files for the article, "Contingency Learning as Binding? Testing an Exemplar View of the Colour-Word Contingency Learning Effect", to be published in the Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology. It includes the data and analysis scripts for the reported statistics along with some supplementary analyses mentioned briefly in the text.

registration_responses.summary: This project contains all the files for the article, "Contingency Learning as Binding? Testing an Exemplar View of the Colour-Word Contingency Learning Effect", to be published in the Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology. It includes the data and analysis scripts for the reported statistics along with some supplementary analyses mentioned briefly in the text.

attributes.title: Interactions between genome-wide polygenic scores for alcohol consumption and a broad spectrum of environmental factors

summary.value: Adolescence is a critical period for experimenting with alcohol, which becomes legally accessible for young people between the ages of 16 and 18 years in the United Kingdom. Genetic factors account on average for about 40% of the differences in alcohol consumption that can be observed between people . Alcohol consumption is a complex behavioural trait that is influenced by many genetic variants, each with very small effect size. Genome-wide polygenic scores (GPS) based on  genome-wide association (GWA) studies have been shown to successfully predict alcohol consumption. Identifying environments that help reducing alcohol consumption among people with greater genetic propensities for drinking is important for successfully tailoring interventions. GPS makes it possible for the first time to directly and robustly test if genetic influences on alcohol consumption change across environmental contexts, a phenomenon known as gene-environment interactions (GxE).   Most previous studies on GxE in alcohol related behaviours have focused on one or two environmental measures as moderators. We seek to extend these works by considering a broad spectrum of environments that are likely to influence the association between the genetic propensity for and actual alcohol consumption, rather than exploring one or two environmental factors. To this end, we will analyse data from TEDS, a large cohort study of twins born in England and Wales between 1992 and 1994, who have completed measures of alcohol related behaviours at age 16 and 21 and on a broad range of environmental conditions.

registration_responses.summary: Adolescence is a critical period for experimenting with alcohol, which becomes legally accessible for young people between the ages of 16 and 18 years in the United Kingdom. Genetic factors account on average for about 40% of the differences in alcohol consumption that can be observed between people . Alcohol consumption is a complex behavioural trait that is influenced by many genetic variants, each with very small effect size. Genome-wide polygenic scores (GPS) based on  genome-wide association (GWA) studies have been shown to successfully predict alcohol consumption. Identifying environments that help reducing alcohol consumption among people with greater genetic propensities for drinking is important for successfully tailoring interventions. GPS makes it possible for the first time to directly and robustly test if genetic influences on alcohol consumption change across environmental contexts, a phenomenon known as gene-environment interactions (GxE).   Most previous studies on GxE in alcohol related behaviours have focused on one or two environmental measures as moderators. We seek to extend these works by considering a broad spectrum of environments that are likely to influence the association between the genetic propensity for and actual alcohol consumption, rather than exploring one or two environmental factors. To this end, we will analyse data from TEDS, a large cohort study of twins born in England and Wales between 1992 and 1994, who have completed measures of alcohol related behaviours at age 16 and 21 and on a broad range of environmental conditions.

attributes.title: Early Attachment Network to Mother and Father
attributes.description: A program of research that examines the quality of infants’ attachment relationships with both parents to evaluate their integrative effects on later life functioning.

summary.value:
Since the seminal 1992 paper by van IJzendoorn, Sagi, and Lambermon, putting forward the “The multiple caretaker paradox”, relatively little attention has been given to the potential joint effects of the role early attachment network to mother and father play in development. Recently, Dagan and Sagi-Schwartz (2018) have published a paper that attempts to revive this unsettled issue, calling for research on the subject and offering a framework for posing attachment network hypotheses. 

This Collaboration for Attachment Research Synthesis project attempts to use an Individual Participant Data meta-analyses to test the hypotheses put forward in Dagan and Sagi-Schwartz (2018). Specifically, we test (a) whether the number of secure attachments (0,1, or 2) matter in predicting a range of developmental outcomes, and (b) whether the quality of attachment relationship with one parent contributes more than the other to these outcomes.

registration_responses.summary:
Since the seminal 1992 paper by van IJzendoorn, Sagi, and Lambermon, putting forward the “The multiple caretaker paradox”, relatively little attention has been given to the potential joint effects of the role early attachment network to mother and father play in development. Recently, Dagan and Sagi-Schwartz (2018) have published a paper that attempts to revive this unsettled issue, calling for research on the subject and offering a framework for posing attachment network hypotheses. 

This Collaboration for Attachment Research Synthesis project attempts to use an Individual Participant Data meta-analyses to test the hypotheses put forward in Dagan and Sagi-Schwartz (2018). Specifically, we test (a) whether the number of secure attachments (0,1, or 2) matter in predicting a range of developmental outcomes, and (b) whether the quality of attachment relationship with one parent contributes more than the other to these outcomes.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Morbidly Curious Behavior: Morbid stimuli inspire more curiosity than non-morbid stimuli

other.value: All of the questionnaire data will be subject to exploratory analysis. Exploratory analyses may also be conducted at the sub-scale level for morbid curiosity. For example, whether or not attention to motives of dangerous people is greater than attention to social violence.

sample.value: Sample size will be determined by the number of participants recruited for the study through the end of the Spring quarter (~ June 1).

analyses.value:
A significance level of 0.05 will be used for all statistical tests.

1) Correlations between the Morbid Curiosity Scale and questionnaire Data (i.e., personality and individual differences) will be analyzed using Pearson's Correlation.

2.1) Eye tracking data (fixations and duration) will be analyzed by using paired t-tests in which attention (duration and fixation separately) to morbid and non-morbid items is compared. I will also perform exploratory analyses on personality data and attention to morbid items. This will be done using Pearson's correlation.

2.2) Choice of morbid stimuli in the computerized task will be analyzed using paired t-tests. Since stimuli in the task fall into 4 categories (corresponding to the 4 factors of the MCS), t-tests will be conducted for each category in the task.  Exploratory analyses will be conducted on the correlation between questionnaire results and choice task results. 

4) Perceptual and Epistemic curiosity for morbid items will be analyzed using paired t-tests for each measure where the values being compared are number of morbid choices and number of non-morbid choices.

outliers.value: Outliers will not be excluded in any main analysis. Participant data may be excluded if it appears they did not take a task seriously or misunderstood the task (e.g., did not inspect the cabinet; press the same key on computerized task for each trial).

dependent.value:
The key dependent variables are:

1) The participants' scores on the Morbid Curiosity Scale (MCS). The score on the MCS (and sub scale scores) will be compared to scores on other personality and individual traits including basic personality (HEXACO), curiosity (Five-Dimensional Curiosity Scale; Epistemic Curiosity Inventory; Perceptual Curiosity Scale), the Autistic-like traits (Autism Spectrum Quotient), psychopathy (Psychopathic Personality Inventory), sociosexuality (Multidimensional Sociosexuality Inventory), and basic demographics. Note- we are not making claims about the MCS being the dependent variable per se, will analyze its correlation with these measures.

2.1) Visual attention to novel morbid stimuli will be measured by quantifying gaze fixation count and gaze duration on 16 different items using a Pupil Invisible eye tracker. Each item is located on a shelf (~ 8"x10") within a cabinet. An area of interest will be drawn around each shelf such that the AOI for the each object is approximately the same size, even if the item size differs. 
2.2) Attention (or preference for information) will also be assessed using a computerized choice task. Here, attention to/preference for morbid stimuli will be measured as the number of morbid stimuli chosen in the task. 

3) Perceptual curiosity (a la Berlyne 1954) will be measured by counting the number of morbid items (out of 5 choices) chosen to pick up and inspect.

4) Epistemic curiosity (a la Berlyne 1954) will be measured by counting the number of morbid items (out of 5 choices) chosen to learn more about.

conditions.value: There is only one condition with 3 parts. Each participant will complete all 3 parts of the study (questionnaires, computerized task, eye tracking/cabinet task).

hypothesis.value:
The main questions being asked in this study are:
1) What are the psychological correlates of trait morbid curiosity (i.e., personality and individual differences in psychological traits)? This is an exploratory question

2) Do individuals pay more attention to novel morbid items than novel items that are not morbid? 
- H1a: On average, participants will spend longer amounts of time inspecting novel morbid items than novel non-morbid items
- H1b: On average, participants will fixate on novel morbid items more times than novel non-morbid items.
- H1c: On average, participants will choose morbid items more often than non-morbid items in the computerized task


3) Given the chance to further inspect some stimulus, will people be more likely to choose the more morbid stimulus for further inspection?
- H2: On average, participants will choose to inspect morbid items more often than non-morbid items.

4) Given the chance to further learn more about some stimulus, will people be more likely to choose the more morbid stimulus to learn more about?
- H3: On average, participants will choose to learn about morbid items more often than non-morbid items.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

attributes.title: How Altering Mortality Salience Manipulations Impacts Terror Management Theory

q1.value: How Altering Mortality Salience Manipulations Impacts Terror Management Theory

q3.value: Terror management theorists assert that reminding individuals of their mortality will cause them to strive to protect their self-esteem through increased adherence to their cultural worldview. This theory presents two competing hypotheses to explain individuals’ reactions to death reminders, i.e., the worldview polarization and conservative shift hypotheses. The purpose of the current research is to investigate the origin of these hypotheses by manipulating how death is primed and by pre-testing political orientation to ensure that a conservative shift or ideological polarization can be clearly identified. The current study seeks to investigate how asking people to think about specific types of death instead of just asking them to think about dying will influence their responses (responses regarding political attitudes and perceptions of meaning in life). Also, this study will investigate how these responses differ when participants are asked to think about a terrifying situation (a negative public speaking experience) instead of death. Additionally, it will further investigate the relationship between various individual differences, and political orientation.

q4.value: This study will consist of five conditions: Sudden Death Mortality Salience condition, Disgusting Death Mortality Salience condition, Non-specified Death Mortality Salience condition, Terror Salience condition, or the Neutral control condition. It has been hypothesized that participants in the Terror Salience condition will score higher on measures of authoritarianism and meaning of life than those in the Neutral condition. Those in the Mortality Salience conditions will score higher on measures of authoritarianism and meaning of life than those in the Terror condition. Those in the Specified Mortality Salience conditions will score higher on measures of authoritarianism and meaning of life than those in the Non-Specified Mortality Salience condition. Finally, those in the Disgust Morality Salience condition will score higher on a measure of authoritarianism than those in the other Mortality Salience conditions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with one factor (mortality salience (MS) manipulation) with five levels (Sudden Death MS prime, Disgusting Death MS prime, Non-specified Death MS prime, Terror Salience prime, and Neutral control prime)

q9.value: Simple randomization will be used to assign participants to one of five conditions. Participants will be assigned to conditions using the web application at https://www.calculatorsoup.com/calculators/statistics/random-number-generator.php

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the University of the Fraser Valley in Abbotsford B.C. Psychology 101 and 102 students will be recruited using the SONA system. Their professors will notify them that they can receive course credit for their participation. Students will also be recruited by asking professors in the political science, philosophy, criminology, and business departments if I can use the end of their class time to conduct this research with students in their class who are willing to stay and participate. Students who are not either in psychology 101 or 102 courses, or in the political science, philosophy, criminology, and business departments will not be included. Participants in psychology 101 and 102 courses who register through the Sona system will receive course credit (1-2%) for their participation. No other compensation will be offered.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 250 participants

question.value: The prompt participants are asked to respond to will be manipulated. Participants will be assigned to one of five conditions: Sudden Death Mortality Salience condition, Disgusting Death Mortality Salience condition, Non-specified Death Mortality Salience condition, Terror Salience condition, or the Neutral control condition. Each manipulation will require participants read a prompt (about dying in specific manner, a terror-inducing public speaking experience, or a neutral situation) and answer two open-ended questions, e.g.,  briefly describe the emotions that the thought of your own death arouses in you and briefly describe as specifically as you can what you believe will happen to you physically as you die, and once you are dead.

The dependent variables will be the degree to which authoritarianism scores changed across conditions (measured before and after the manipulation) and perceptions of meaning in life. To measure authoritarianism, participants will be instructed to complete a measure of child-rearing values. For each item, this questionnaire requires participants to indicate which of two qualities they believe are most desirable for a child to have or if they believe that both qualities are equally desirable. This measure is an expanded version of the four-item measure created by Feldman and Stenner (1997).  Participants will respond to 10-items before the experimental manipulation and another 10-items after. To measure perceptions of meaning in life, participants will be asked to indicate their level of agreement with 17 statements that assess their sense of significance, purpose, and coherence regarding their life.

T-tests will be performed for each of the comparisons with Bonferroni correction to control for familywise error. The comparisons will be: MS conditions and Neutral condition (Authoritarianism and Meaning in life), Terror condition and Neutral condition (Authoritarianism and Meaning in life), Terror condition and MS conditions (Authoritarianism and Meaning in life), Specified MS conditions and Non-specified MS condition (Authoritarianism and Meaning in life), Disgusting MS condition and other two MS conditions (Authoritarianism). Additionally, the Pearson correlation coefficient will be used to analyze the relationship between attachment style (measured using the Revised Adult Attachment Scale (Collins, 1996)-Close Relationships Version) and authoritarianism, and various personality dimensions (measured using the honesty-humility, conscientiousness, emotionality, and openness to experience scales of the HEXACO-60 item questionnaire) and authoritarianism. The Pearson correlation coefficient will also be used to evaluate whether the post-test scores for the child-rearing values questionnaire correlate with responses to six items from the right-wing authoritarianism scale.

q21.value: Bonferroni correction will be used to control for familywise error for the two families of t-tests (one for each of the dependent measures).

q22.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis

q23.value: If a participant does not complete one of the dependent measures their data will not be included in the analysis for that measure. Additionally, if a participant does not respond to the prompt included in the manipulation their data will not be included.

The purpose of the current research is to investigate the origin of these hypotheses by manipulating how death is primed and by pre-testing political orientation to ensure that a conservative shift or ideological polarization can be clearly identified. The current study seeks to investigate how asking people to think about specific types of death instead of just asking them to think about dying will influence their responses (responses regarding political attitudes and perceptions of meaning in life). Also, this study will investigate how these responses differ when participants are asked to think about a terrifying situation (a negative public speaking experience) instead of death. Additionally, it will further investigate the relationship between various individual differences, and political orientation.

Those in the Specified Mortality Salience conditions will score higher on measures of authoritarianism and meaning of life than those in the Non-Specified Mortality Salience condition. Finally, those in the Disgust Morality Salience condition will score higher on a measure of authoritarianism than those in the other Mortality Salience conditions.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: The effects of HIV and drug use stigma on treatment for opioid use disorder among people living with HIV in Vietnam

other.value: This is a secondary analysis of data from a clinical trial comparing buprenorphine and methadone for HIV viral suppression. The trial is complete, and analyses of the primary outcomes are underway. The proposed analyses are independent of the primary analyses for this study.

sample.value: The sample size is N = 281 participants measured at baseline + 4 timepoints for a total of 1,405 observations

analyses.value:
We will estimate the effects of stigma-lowering interventions on study outcomes using the parametric g-computation formula for time-varying exposures and confounding. 

In this analysis, we will consider an intervention occurring after baseline but before the 3-month follow-up visit. Our casual effect estimate is the population-average treatment effect (PATE), e.g., the expected difference in outcomes (e.g. MOUD exposure over 12 months) if everyone were given the intervention vs. the same quantity if no one was given the intervention.

We will estimate the effects of a number of hypothetical interventions delivered to the entire study population:
1- An individual-level intervention shortly after baseline that reduces individuals' baseline stigma by 25%, 50%, or 75%, compared to no intervention
2- A population-level intervention simulating what would happen if we could "set" the entire study population to have low stigma (defined as the 10th percentile, first quartile, and first tertile of the observed stigma variable(s)) compared to no intervention. 

We will also consider the impact of "refresher" interventions given at study midpoint, i.e., a second "dose" of stigma-lowering intervention shortly after the 6-month visit.

We include two time-varying covariates, social support and methamphetamine use. Time-fixed (baseline) covariates include randomized group, age, education level, employment, marital status, disclosure of HIV status to partner, CD4+ T-cell count, severity of opioid addiction (DSMV), as well as baseline HIV and drug use stigma.

outliers.value: No observations will be excluded. Missing data will be handled by multiple imputation with chained equations.

dependent.value:
We will study two key dependent variables:

1.	Number of days exposed to medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD; buprenorphine or methadone) over 12 months as determined by medical chart abstraction 
2.	The likelihood of positive heroin urine drug screen (UDS) at 3 months (directly following "intervention") and the average likelihood across all 4 study visits

conditions.value: There are two exposures of interest: HIV stigma and drug use stigma. We will consider “intervention” on each type of stigma separately as well as a joint intervention on both stigmas. We will also consider type of MOUD (buprenorphine vs. methadone) as an effect modifier.

hypothesis.value:
Aim: To estimate the impacts of HIV and drug use stigma, separately and in combination, on treatment for opioid use disorder among people living with HIV in Vietnam. 

Hypothesis: We hypothesize that higher levels of stigma, especially drug use stigma, will result in reduced engagement in medication treatment for opioid use disorder and, consequently, higher likelihood of continued opioid use over time.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

registration_responses.hypothesis:
Aim: To estimate the impacts of HIV and drug use stigma, separately and in combination, on treatment for opioid use disorder among people living with HIV in Vietnam. 

Hypothesis: We hypothesize that higher levels of stigma, especially drug use stigma, will result in reduced engagement in medication treatment for opioid use disorder and, consequently, higher likelihood of continued opioid use over time.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

attributes.title: Are features perceived to be useful actually more useful? An expertise effect
attributes.description: The aim of this experiment is to determine whether experts, relative to novices, are more sensitive to the features that are useful and unuseful. We set out to test a) whether the expert-chosen useful features are more useful than novice-chosen useful features, and b) whether the expert-chosen unuseful features are less useful than the novice-chosen unuseful features.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

attributes.title: Spring 2020 in the Lab: Readings to reduce misconceptions, and to reduce future backsliding
attributes.description: We have demonstrated that we can reduce misconceptions using text if we co-activate both the misconception and the factual information and make an explicit connection between the two. We want to show that this change can be maintained over time with the introduction of an additional explanation of the cognitive biases and fallacies that lead to the misconception.

q1.value: Reading to reduce misconceptions, and to reduce future backsliding: Spring 2020 Lab Study

q3.value: We have demonstrated that we can reduce misconceptions with readings that co-activate both the misconception and the factual information, and make an explicit connection between the two. We want to show that this reduction can be maintained over time with the introduction of an explanation of the cognitive biases and fallacies that lead to the misconception.

q4.value: Long-term change in prior false beliefs (misconceptions) will be greater when a text has three elements: co-activation of the misconception and a factual statement, an explanation of the scientific facts regarding the misconception, and an explanation of the logical fallacy or cognitive bias which often leads a person to believe the misconception, to begin with.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
Mixed factorial design with a within-subjects longitudinal component and a between-subjects manipulation of text types, as well as a between-subjects manipulation of different misconception items (4 items).  Each participant will read a different version of the same basic text; there will be 3 versions of each of 4 texts.
Participants will first complete a 10-item forced-choice questionnaire and will then randomly receive one of three versions of a four different text over the selected misconceptions. The three different components in each text include (1) Activation (the misconception expressly stated) (A), (2) Evidence for the correct information (E), and (3) Immunization from backsliding; this provides an explanation of why it's a misconception and the failure of scientific thinking, cognitive bias or logical fallacy at play. The readings combine into three types (conditions):
(1) yes 'A', yes 'I', yes 'E';
(2) yes 'A', yes 'I', no 'E'; (this allows comparison of immunization to no immunization)
(3) no 'A', yes 'I', no 'E' (this is the standard condition in most current texts wherein only the current evidence-based is presented; this allows a comparison of activation to no activation (conditions 2 versus 3))

The four misconception/reading topics include catharsis makes you feel better; students have different learning styles; getting a chill causes you to catch a cold; boosting self-esteem improves school performance. 
Four months afterward they will again complete the same 10-item forced-choice questionnaire.

q9.value: Participants will be assigned to groups based on their arrival into the lab. We will not know the entire sample before making the study available. Readings will be prepared in text packets that reflect a Latin square arrangement of conditions (3 x 4) for the manipulated between-subjects variables and placed in a pile. As participants arrive they will receive the next packet in the pile, with multiples of 12 packets repeating in the same order. Thus, any given participant will only read about all four topics, but one topic text condition will repeat itself.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from our introductory psychology student research participation pool. They will receive two credits for participation. The only stipulation will be that participants must be 18-years of age or older. We plan to run the study during the last week of January. Following the first participation, we will follow up with online testing in mid-February and again in late May.

q13.value:
GPower analysis:
F tests - ANOVA: Repeated measures, within-between interaction
Analysis:	A priori: Compute the required sample size 
Input:	
        Effect size f	=	0.25
	α err prob	=	0.01
	Power (1-β err prob)	=	0.95
	Number of groups	=	12
	Number of measurements	=	3
	Corr among rep measures	=	0.5
	Nonsphericity correction ε	=	1
Output:	Noncentrality parameter λ	=	45.0000000
	Critical F	=	1.9182140
	Numerator df	=	22.0000000
	Denominator df	=	216
	Total sample size	=	120
	Actual power	=	0.9565566

q14.value: Given the constraints of the size of our participant pool and the knowledge that all potential students will not choose to participate, we anticipate obtaining 50 participants, well below the GPower analysis indication. We may need to continue with a new add-on sample, in Fall 2020.

q15.value: No need for a stopping rule; more participants would be better but we do not have access to more.

question.value:
The text type reading conditions include three components in different arrangements: Activation (A), Evidence (E), Immunization (I). 
The three combined conditions for this study are:
(1) yes 'A', yes 'E', yes 'I'; all components present.
(2) yes 'A', yes 'E', no 'I'; (this allows comparison of immunization to no immunization)
(3) no 'A', yes 'E', no 'I' (this is the standard condition in most current texts - just the facts)
The no immunization conditions include additional text that is related to the topic of the misconception but irrelevant to the accuracy of the factual information regarding the misconception. This allows for an approximately equal length of each reading, within a topic area controlling an alternative explanation of reading length.
All readings within a topic area will also be as close as possible in reading level as calculated by Microsoft Office Word in terms of Flesch reading ease and Flesch-Kincaid grade level.  
The four misconceptions/reading topics include catharsis makes you feel better; students have different learning styles; getting cold causes one to catch a cold; boosting self-esteem improves school performance.
Thus, each participant will read four readings, with one repeated text type. Booklets with readings will be prepared in a fashion such that for every 12 participants we will have distributed every set of possible combinations of the four readings in three different text types. A complete Latin square design will be applied.
We will use the same 10-item questionnaire at pretest, immediate posttest, 4 months posttest.

We are going to combine via multiplication the accuracy and confidence variables such that correct answers will be scored as '1' and multiplied by confidence and incorrect answers will be scored as '-1' and multiplied by confidence. Thus, any given response will range from -5 to 5. We believe this gives a more sensitive measure of change because even if a student fails to correct their misconception, they may become less confident in the misconception.

We will use a between/within ANOVA. The within variable is time with testings occurring immediately before and after the readings and then again in 4 months. We expect a main effect of test time such that for those items on the pretest for which there are readings scores will increase from pretest to posttest and will remain high; this may be moderated by (interaction effect) the type of text such that having all three components, activation, explanation, and immunization from backsliding will result in maintenance of high accuracy across time; lower accuracy over time (backsliding) without immunization. We expect that the explanation only condition will result in immediate posttest elevation of scores with a gradual backslide. We expect that activation and explanation will result in a similar immediate posttest elevation but with a less pronounced backslide. We are not sure about this condition as in the past we found that for some misconceptions, such as catharsis, there is no backslide even without the immunization from a backsliding component. Thus, the exact nature of the expected interaction may vary based on the topic of the misconception, and this is more of an exploratory question as we only have our own previous studies to base this on.  
The independent-groups variable includes the type of text, which is the key variable, but  we will analyze for the several misconceptions as well. In the past we found that each misconception tends to behave independently of the other. This latter is again more exploratory to compare to our previous data. Almost all studies in the published literature examine one misconception at a time. Finally, the pretest includes items that reflect misconceptions from other disciplines--more generalized misconceptions about general knowledge (e.g., the reason for seasons). Since we will be asking students for their majors we are going to explore whether major or intended major, affects their knowledge and any changes in knowledge for items that match their background more closely (e.g., there are items from physics and biology).

q20.value: We will also look at participant variables such as gender and major so these will be simply coded with dummy variables. Gender will be 1,2 female, male (alphabetic mapping which helps me remember which is which) but since we don't yet know all the potential majors that will have to wait following the same alphabetic mapping to dummy numbers.

q21.value: We are going to use p-values with effect size and 95% confidence intervals to make final assessments. Thus, despite a p-value below .05, we will take into account that low effect sizes with huge confidence intervals may result in very cautious conclusions.

q23.value: Exclusion will only occur if the statistical test requires complete data; that is, for the longitudinal variable we will certainly have mortality and may need to only analyze those cases where a participant has a complete data set at all testing times.

q24.value:
We are also asking participants to underline/highlight key components of each reading, with instructions to do so as if they were reading a text for a class. We hypothesize that participants will focus in on the key facts that counter the misconception.   
Analyses of the differences between specific misconceptions will be exploratory, as will be various participant variables. We are asking for permission to access their verbal achievement test scores (SAT or ACT) as a measure of verbal comprehension ability. In the past we have found that students with poor verbal comprehension performed worse, that is, were less likely to show a change, simply because of their difficulty with understanding readings. Finally, the underlining/highlighting of text will be exploratory.
Many of the demographic variables are included for exploratory purposes. We have found in the past that SAT/ACT verbal scores predicted change in misconception endorsement. We will again obtain SAT/ACT verbal scores

q25.value:
Previous studies we have reported and that form a basis for the current work include these:
Kowalski, P., & Taylor, A. (2019). “Well, that didn’t work!” or How attempting to reduce misconceptions in psychology reveals the challenges of change. In P. Kendeou & D. H. Robinson, (Eds.) Misinformation, ‘quackery,’ and ‘fake news’ in education. Charlotte, NC: Information Age Publishing.
Kowalski, P., & Taylor, A. K. (2017). Reducing students’ misconceptions with refutational teaching: For long-term retention, verbal ability matters. Journal of the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning in Psychology, 3(2), 90-100. http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/stl0000082
Kowalski, P., & Taylor, A. (2009). The effect of refuting misconceptions in the psychology classroom. Teaching of Psychology, 36(3), 153-159.
Other relevant research:
Kendeou, P., Walsh, E. K., Smith, E. R., & O’Brien, E. J. (2014). Knowledge revision processes in refutation texts. Discourse Processes, 51, 374–397.
Lewandowsky, S., Ecker, U. K. H., Seifert, C. M., Schwarz, N., & Cook, J. (2012). Misinformation and its correction: Continued influence and successful debiasing. Psychological Science in the Public Interest 13(3), 106–131.
Trevors, G. J., Muis K. R., Pekrun, R., Sinatra, G. M., & Winne, P. H. (2016). Identity and epistemic emotions during knowledge revision: A potential account for the backfire effect. Discourse Processes, 53, 339–370.

attributes.title: Low-cost, open-source, variable speed and incline treadmill for studying neonatal locomotion

summary.value: This registration includes all the materials associated with the HardwareX manuscript, Low-cost, open-source, variable speed and incline treadmill for studying impacts of neonatal locomotion.

registration_responses.summary: This registration includes all the materials associated with the HardwareX manuscript, Low-cost, open-source, variable speed and incline treadmill for studying impacts of neonatal locomotion.
